column1: Fort Leonard Wood is a U.S. Army training installation located in the Missouri Ozarks. The main gate is located on the southern boundary of The City of St. Robert. The post was created in December 1940 and named in honor of General Leonard Wood (former Chief of Staff) in January 1941. Originally intended to train infantry troops
column2: in 1941 it became an engineer training post with the creation of the Engineer Replacement Training Center. During World War II Italian and German POWs were interned at the fort.
as part of the Base Realignment and Closure process
column3: most of the U.S. Army Engineer School's operations were consolidated at Fort Leonard Wood. Before that
column4: officer training was conducted at Fort Belvoir
column6: again as part of the Base Realignment and Closure process
column9: and the U.S. Army Chemical Corps and Military Police Corps schools were transferred to Fort Leonard Wood
column10: which was concurrently redesignated the U.S. Army Maneuver Support Center.In 2009
column11: the U.S. Army Maneuver Support Center was redesignated the U.S. Army Maneuver Support Center of Excellence (MSCoE); the "center of excellence" designation was placed on almost all U.S. Army training institutions.The current commanding general is Brigadier General James Bonner and the command sergeant major is Command Sergeant Major James Breckinridge.

column1: == History ==
Prior to the establishment of the current Fort Leonard Wood
column2: the name was used in 1928 to rename Camp Meade in central Maryland when it was decided that the facility

column1: The installation has historically had a training role under TRADOC (Training and Doctrine Command) rather than a FORSCOM (Forces Command) role dating back to its origins in World War II as an engineer replacement training post. During the Gulf War
column2: the 5th Engineer Battalion from the fort saw action in the Middle East.After the beginning of the current wars in Iraq and Afghanistan
column3: the 94th Engineer Battalion was restationed from Germany to Fort Leonard Wood
column4: as were the 92nd Military Police Battalion
column6: and 94th Signal Company (part of the 4th Maneuver Enhancement Brigade). The 4th Maneuver Enhancement Brigade was activated at the fort on 2 October 2008 and was inactivated June 17

column1: == Geography ==
Fort Leonard Wood is located at 37°44′17″N 92°7′2″W (37.738191
column2: −92.117275).According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the base has a total area of 97.6 square miles (252.8 km2)
column4: of which 97.2 square miles (251.7 km2) is land and 0.4 square miles (1.1 km2) (0.43%) is water.

column1: == Initial Entry Training ==
The Maneuver Support Center of Excellence offers Basic Combat Training (BCT) for most non-combat arms soldiers
column2: and Advanced Individual Training (AIT) for MOS (Military Occupational Specialty) 88M (motor transport operator) and MOS 74D (Chemical
column3: Biological
column5: and Nuclear specialists). It also provides non-combat engineer MOS training
column6: OSUT (One-Station Unit Training) for combat engineers and bridging engineers (MOS 12B and 12C)
column8: 31K & 31E). All training is gender integrated as is Fort Jackson.Newly commissioned second lieutenants in the CBRN
column10: and Military Police branches attend the Basic Officer Leader Course Phase B at the Maneuver Support Center of Excellence.

column1: == Continuing education ==
The Maneuver Support Center of Excellence NCO Academy conducts the Senior and Advanced Leader Courses for the Chemical
column2: Engineer
column3: and Military Police branches
column4: the Advanced Leader Course for Ordnance NCOs in MOS 62B
column5: and the Warrior Leader Course for all Army NCO MOSs.The CBRN
column7: and Military Police schools provide Professional Military Education and functional courses for soldiers
column11: including but not limited to the Captains Career Course and the Battalion and Brigade Pre-Command Courses.

column1: == Transportation ==
Waynesville-St. Robert Regional Airport provides the community with air service. Although it is on Fort Leonard Wood
column2: the airport is jointly run by the cities of Waynesville and St. Robert
column3: and is available for civilian use by private pilots and scheduled commercial passenger service.

column1: The major east-west route is  Interstate 44; before its construction
column2: the main highway was  U.S. Route 66
column3: which still exists as a scenic route through the area and passes through Devil's Elbow
column7: and Hazelgreen. Names for U.S. Route 66 vary – at different places
column12: and  Route 17. State-posted signs mark most of the alignment of the road.

column1: Major north-south routes include:
Route 133 runs north from Interstate 44
column2: exit 145
column3: approximately two miles east of Hazelgreen to Richland
column6: and about two miles west of Dixon
column7: then north out of the county.

column1: Route 7 runs north from Interstate 44
column2: exit 150 about three miles west of Buckhorn to Richland
column3: then north out of the county toward the Lake of the Ozarks region.

column1: Route 17 crosses Interstate 44 at exit 153 at Buckhorn
column2: runs east through Waynesville
column3: turns north to Crocker
column4: and then runs north out of the county to Iberia. South of Interstate 44
column5: Highway 17 hugs the western edge of Fort Leonard Wood
column7: and circles south of the post until it runs out of the county and eventually joins Highway 32 in Roby.

column1: Highway T runs north from Highway 17 at Waynesville to Swedeborg
column2: where it meets and ends at Highway 133 about halfway between Richland and Crocker.

column1: Route 28 crosses Interstate 44 at exit 163 at the eastern edge of St. Robert
column2: runs north through Dixon
column3: and then runs north out of the county.

column1: A secondary road parallels Missouri 28
column2: beginning as  Highway Y at exit 161 of Interstate 44 in St. Robert
column3: running north to the Gasconade River bridge
column4: where it becomes the county-maintained Cave Road and turning north as  Highway O until it meets Highway 28
column5: a few miles south of Dixon.Major attractions along U.S. Route 66 include the Old Stagecoach Stop in downtown Waynesville
column6: which is now a museum but began as a tavern and boarding house and is the oldest standing structure in the county. It was used as a Civil War hospital for Union troops who were garrisoned above the city in Fort Wayne
column7: which was demolished after the war. The Old Courthouse Museum in downtown Waynesville is near the Old Stagecoach Stop. Three bridges cross the Big Piney River at Devil's Elbow—the modern Interstate 44 bridge
column8: the later U.S. Route 66 alignment on Highway Z that was made possible by the Hooker Cut through a steep hillside
column9: and the original U.S. Route 66 alignment on Teardrop Road that includes a historic bridge that is in the process of renovation. The Elbow Inn is a biker bar that is a frequent stop on the original U.S. Route 66 alignment.Fort Leonard Wood also has its own post utility railway connecting to the national railway system. The rail system is operated by a contractor
column12: primarily carrying heavy equipment in support of the training center. Consisting of 27 miles of track
column13: 18 of which connect the post with BNSF Railway at Bundy Junction
column14: its operations are conducted from Monday through Friday
column15: 0800 to 1600. The system uses two EMD GP10 locomotives numbered USA 4606 and USA 4607 and one GP40-2 numbered USA 4654. Previous motive power consisted of USA 2002 and USA 2024
column16: EMD SW8 locomotives built in 1951 that had been used by army railway operating battalions in Korea during the war. The post also had two GE 80-ton centercab locomotives for on-post switching.Most of the main line between the post and Bundy Junction has a grade 1.5% grade
column17: and in some places it reaches 3%. The grade is so steep that only 20 cars can be pulled at a time up or down the mainline. The line has four sidings used for storing rail cars. At one time the line had centralized traffic control (CTC) signals
column18: but today the signals and CTC equipment are long gone.At one time
column19: Fort Leonard Wood featured a busy rail operation. Not only did it receive vehicles and containers by rail
column20: but also boxcars full of goods and equipment
column21: coal for the base power plant
column22: propane for various functions around post
column23: and even diesel fuel for vehicles.Today all that remains are half a dozen tracks with loading ramps on the ends
column24: located in a warehouse area. In addition
column25: there is a small staging yard next to the warehouses
column26: an engine house and a small wye. The engine house was extended so that both locomotives can fit inside.

column1: == Media ==
Fort Leonard Wood is in Pulaski County and a high percentage of military personnel live off post in surrounding communities
column2: especially St. Robert and Waynesville but also the farther-out cities of Richland
column3: Crocker
column5: and the unincorporated communities of Laquey
column7: all of which have a lower housing cost than nearer housing in St. Robert and Waynesville. Military personnel assigned to training areas on the south end of the post sometimes choose to live in the unincorporated areas of Big Piney and Palace in Pulaski County
column8: or the northern Texas County communities of Plato and Roby.

column1: The area has one daily and three weekly print newspapers
column2: as well as an online internet daily newspaper. The county also has two internet discussion sites
column3: the Pulaski County Web and Pulaski County Insider.

column1: KFBD-FM and its AM sister station
column2: KJPW
column3: are among the news providers in the Pulaski County area

column1: KFLW Radio is owned by Ozark Media and is the only locally owned and operated radio station in Pulaski County. KFLW 98.9 The Fort is heavily involved in the local communities it serves and is known for its support of not only Fort Leonard Wood
column2: but military service members in general.

column1: The content of the weekly Fort Leonard Wood Guidon is produced under the auspices of Army Public Affairs at Fort Leonard Wood but printed under contract by the Springfield News-Leader
column2: a Gannett-owned newspaper which produces and sells advertisements in the Fort Leonard Wood Guidon.

column1: The Daily Guide
column2: commonly known as the Waynesville Daily Guide but based in St. Robert and serving the entire county
column3: is owned by Gatehouse Media and is the central printing plant for three other Gatehouse newspapers in nearby counties
column6: and Rolla Daily News as well as the weekly St. James Leader-Journal.The weekly Pulaski County Mirror is owned by the Lebanon Daily Record
column7: a family owned newspaper in an adjoining county. The paper is a merger of the Richland Mirror and Pulaski County Democrat in St. Robert
column8: which were separate weekly papers owned by the Lebanon Daily Record until their owner merged them in 2009.

column1: The weekly Dixon Pilot is privately owned by a resident of Dixon.The Pulaski County Breaking News internet newspaper is privately owned by a Former Devils Elbow resident.
The Pulaski County Daily News internet newspaper is privately owned by a St. Robert resident.
The Pulaski County Insider is run by a group of St. Robert and Waynesville residents and maintained and hosted by a Potosi resident.
The Pulaski County Web is run and maintained by a Devil's Elbow resident and former St. Robert businessman.
== School districts ==
Seven main school districts are fully or partly within the borders of Pulaski County
column2: not counting two small districts which are mostly within other counties and only have only a few dozen residents within Pulaski County. All seven school districts have a high percentage of Fort Leonard Wood military dependents
column3: and over two-thirds of Waynesville students fall into that category.The cities of Waynesville and St. Robert and the Fort Leonard Wood army installation
column4: along with their surrounding rural areas running east to Devil's Elbow
column5: are served by the Waynesville R-VI School District which is by far the largest in the county.The cities of Richland
column8: along with their surrounding rural areas
column9: are served by the Richland R-IV School District
column10: the Crocker R-II School District and the Dixon R-I School District. The Richland and Dixon districts both extend into rural parts of adjacent counties.The unincorporated communities of Laquey and Swedeborg are served by the Laquey R-V School District and the Swedeborg R-III School District. Swedeborg is the county's last remaining K–8 district and most of its high school students attend Richland High School though some attend Crocker High School or Waynesville High School; all others serve students running from kindergarten through high school.The areas south of Fort Leonard Wood
column11: including the unincorporated Pulaski County communities of Big Piney and Palace
column12: is served by the Plato R-V School District
column13: which is based in the northern Texas County village of Plato but also includes parts of Pulaski

column1: == New Year's Eve tornado ==
On the morning hours of 31 December 2010
column2: an EF3 tornado had touched down near the army base's training and cantonment area (east side of the base). It caused damage to many houses
column3: government buildings
column4: and an old house built during the World War II era. The most damage was in the North Piney Hills Housing Area. There were only minor injuries.
